title: Lady Anne's Way Walking Route

images.title: Skipton Castle by Philip Halling, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Skipton Castle near the start of the walk.

images.title: Lady Anne's Way at Thrang by David Brown, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lady Anne's Way at Thrang

images.title: John Illingworth / The High Way
images.caption: The High Way. This is an old road from Mallerstang to Wensleydale. It is now know part of Lady Anne's Way, named after the indomitable Lady Anne Clifford who travelled this route between her properties.

images.title: John Walton / Ford at Mallerstang
images.caption: Ford at Mallerstang. This is the first of a series of fords on the 'Old Road', part of the 100 mile long Lady Anne's Way.

images.title: ronnie leask / Pendragon Castle
images.caption: Pendragon Castle. This 12th century castle is located just south of Kirkby Stephen on the trail. Lady Anne rebuilt the castle in 1660, adding a brewhouse, bakehouse, stables and coach-house. It remained one of the favourites among her many castles until her death in 1676 at the age of 86.

images.title: Garsdale Head by David Brown, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Garsdale Head

description: This long distance trail runs for about 100 miles from Skipton in Yorkshire to Penrith in Cumbria. Starting in Skipton you will pass Skipton Castle before heading to Grassington, Buckden, Askrigg, Bolton Abbey, Garsdale Head, Kirkby Stephen , Great Ormside, Appleby-in-Westmorland and Penrith where the route finishes close to Penrith Castle. There's much to enjoy with some challenging climbs, long riverside sections, striking limenstone pavement and wonderful views over the Yorkshire Dales and the Eden Valley. The route is named after Lady Anne Clifford who renovated several of the historic Clifford family buildings you will pass on the way. These include the Barden Tower on the edge of the wonderful Bolton Abbey Estate. The trail also links up with the Dales Way and the Dales High Way at various points so you could create alterante walks using these waymarked trails.
display_address: Craven Bakery, 3, Otley Street, Middle Town, Skipton, North Yorkshire, York and North Yorkshire, England, BD23 1DY, United Kingdom
